qas.question: What is the difference in time between the calendars?
With what other difference did the Gregorian calendar concern itself?
When was the vernal equinox at the end of the third century?
In order to account for the full moon coming after the equinox, when was the equinox set?
How did the Gregorian calendar set these same of the full moon not preceding Easterconditions?
What changed the length of the calendar year from 365.2425 days to 365.25 days?
What was reduced by forty-eight minutes and ten seconds?
What was not to follow the equinox?
What was March 22 the latest date for?

context: In addition to the change in the mean length of the calendar year from 365.25 <b6_0>days<b6_0/> (365 days 6 hours) to 365.2425 days (365 days 5 hours 49 minutes 12 seconds), a reduction of <a0_0>10 minutes 48 seconds<a0_0/> per year, the <b5_0>Gregorian calendar reform<b5_0/> also dealt with the <a1_0>accumulated difference<a1_0/> between these lengths. <b7_0>The canonical <b9_0>Easter<b9_0/> tables<b7_0/> were devised at the end of the third century, when the vernal equinox fell either on <a2_0>20 March or 21 March<a2_0/> depending on the year's position in the leap year cycle. As the rule was that the full moon preceding <b8_0>Easter<b8_0/> was not to precede the equinox the equinox was fixed at 21 March for computational purposes and the earliest date for Easter was fixed at <a3_0>22 March<a3_0/>. The Gregorian calendar reproduced these conditions by <a4_0>removing ten days<a4_0/>.
